conflictDescription: User Story A requires the nurse to communicate with the informal caregiver without involving the patient, which implies starting communication without the patient's initiation. User Story B requires that the older adult controls all communications and only allows chats they start, forbidding any communication not initiated by them. These two requirements contradict each other on the operation of starting communication.
userStoryASummary: As a registered nurse, I want to discuss care adjustments with the informal caregiver without involving the patient, so I can keep clinical safety and avoid distractions.
userStoryBSummary: As an older adult, I want to control all communication with family and friends and avoid unwanted messages, allowing only chats I initiate.
resolutionDescription: Both user stories are updated to allow communication control with clear consent rules. The nurse can communicate with the informal caregiver without patient involvement only when the patient consents, respecting the older adult's control over initiated chats.
newUserStoryASummary: As a registered nurse, I want to discuss care adjustments with the informal caregiver with the patient's consent, so I can keep clinical safety and avoid distractions.
newUserStoryBSummary: As an older adult, I want to control all communication and allow chats only with my consent, so I avoid unwanted messages.

conflictDescription: User Story A wants nurses to discuss care adjustments without involving the patient, which may include unannounced contacts, while User Story B forbids nurse visits or calls without prior arrangement by the older person. These opposite expectations about nurse contact timing and patient involvement create a Start-Forbid conflict.
userStoryASummary: As a registered nurse, I want to discuss care adjustments with the informal caregiver without involving the patient, so I can keep clinical safety and avoid distractions.
userStoryBSummary: As an older person, I want to arrange nurse check-ins only at home and by myself, so that I keep full control and avoid surprise visits or calls.
resolutionDescription: Both user stories are updated to define nurse contact with prior consent from the older person, allowing discussions with caregivers only after patient agreement to avoid surprise visits and ensure safety.
newUserStoryASummary: As a registered nurse, I want to discuss care adjustments with the informal caregiver after the patient's consent, so I can keep clinical safety and respect privacy.
newUserStoryBSummary: As an older person, I want to arrange nurse visits or calls in advance, so I keep control and avoid surprise contacts.

conflictDescription: The nurse wants to schedule check-ins only during hospital work hours, while the older person wants to schedule check-ins only at home by themselves. These conditions for scheduling check-ins are different and cannot happen at the same time.
userStoryASummary: As a registered nurse, I want to plan patient check-ins only during work hours at the hospital, so I can avoid unplanned contacts and focus on clinical care.
userStoryBSummary: As an older person, I want to arrange nurse check-ins only at home and by myself, so that I keep full control and avoid surprise visits or calls.
resolutionDescription: The conflict is resolved by updating both stories to allow nurse check-ins at home during hospital work hours, balancing control and scheduling needs.
newUserStoryASummary: As a registered nurse, I want to plan patient check-ins at home during hospital work hours, so I can schedule visits efficiently and avoid unplanned contacts.
newUserStoryBSummary: As an older person, I want to arrange nurse check-ins only at home during hospital work hours, so I keep control and avoid surprise visits.

conflictDescription: User Story A wants check-ins only during hospital work hours, while User Story B wants check-ups only at home arranged by themselves. These are opposite expectations on the location and timing of check-ins, which cannot happen at the same time.
userStoryASummary: As a registered nurse, I want to plan patient check-ins only during work hours at the hospital, so I can avoid unplanned contacts and focus on clinical care.
userStoryBSummary: As an older person, I want check-ups only at my home and arranged by me, so I feel safe and avoid hospitals or remote visits.
resolutionDescription: Both user stories are updated to allow check-ins to be planned by nurses during hospital work hours or at home arranged by the user, using a context-aware policy to respect user preferences and care schedules.
newUserStoryASummary: As a nurse, I want to plan patient check-ins during hospital hours or at home, so I can organize care without unplanned visits.
newUserStoryBSummary: As an older person, I want to arrange my check-ups at home or hospital hours, so I feel safe and keep control of visits.

conflictDescription: User Story A requires video check-ins to be only about medical issues, forbidding other video calls, while User Story B wants to start video calls for social contact with a niece. These are opposite instructions about video call usage.
userStoryASummary: As a registered nurse, I want video check-ins to be only about medical issues to avoid distractions and focus on health.
userStoryBSummary: As an older person, I want to start a video call with my niece using ALFRED, so that I can stay connected easily when I prefer digital contact.
resolutionDescription: Both user stories are updated to specify video calls purpose: medical video check-ins are limited to health topics, while social video calls are allowed for family connection under separate contexts.
newUserStoryASummary: As a registered nurse, I want video check-ins to focus only on medical issues, so that health monitoring is clear and effective.
newUserStoryBSummary: As an older person, I want to start video calls with my niece for social contact, so that I can stay connected easily.

conflictDescription: User Story A wants video check-ins only about medical issues, forbidding other topics during video chats, while User Story B wants to play brain games during chats, allowing non-medical activities. These impose opposite expectations on the chat content at the same time.
userStoryASummary: As a registered nurse, I want video check-ins to be only about medical issues to avoid distractions and focus on health.
userStoryBSummary: As an older adult, I want to play brain games during chats with different difficulty levels, so I can stay active and enjoy time with friends.
resolutionDescription: The conflict is resolved by allowing video check-ins to focus on medical issues but permitting brain games during separate or designated social chat sessions, separating medical from social interactions.
newUserStoryASummary: As a registered nurse, I want video check-ins focused only on medical issues, so that health discussions stay clear and focused.
newUserStoryBSummary: As an older adult, I want to play brain games during social chats, so I can stay active and enjoy time with friends.

conflictDescription: User Story A expects the system to start video calls initiated by caregivers for guided exercises, while User Story B forbids any communication unless initiated by the older adult user. These are opposite instructions for the same event of starting communication.
userStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to use video calls for guided exercises with my clients so I can connect with them and support their activity.
userStoryBSummary: As an older adult, I want to control all communication with family and friends and avoid unwanted messages, allowing only chats I initiate.
resolutionDescription: Apply a context-aware policy that allows caregiver-initiated video calls only when the older adult user consents or during scheduled exercise sessions, ensuring the older adult controls communication while enabling caregiver support.
newUserStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to start video calls for guided exercises with my clients only with their consent, so I can support their activity respectfully.
newUserStoryBSummary: As an older adult, I want to control all communication and only allow video calls from caregivers when I agree or during planned sessions, to avoid unwanted messages.

conflictDescription: User Story A wants to stop automatic sharing of private data except in emergencies, forbidding frequent data sharing, while User Story B wants many health and exercise updates to know status. These requirements conflict because one forbids frequent data sharing and the other requires frequent updates.
userStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to stop automatic sharing of my clients' private data except in emergencies, to keep their trust and privacy safe.
userStoryBSummary: As an older adult, I want ALFRED to give me many health and exercise updates so I can always know how I am doing.
resolutionDescription: Adjust both stories so data sharing is limited to essential and emergency updates, balancing privacy and health awareness.
newUserStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to limit automatic sharing of private data to emergencies and essential updates, so privacy is protected.
newUserStoryBSummary: As an older adult, I want ALFRED to provide important health and exercise updates, so I can stay informed without frequent data sharing.

conflictDescription: User Story A expects ALFRED to support activities clients enjoy, which may include prompting or initiating communications. User Story B forbids any communication unless initiated by the older adult, creating opposite expectations about system-initiated communication.
userStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want ALFRED to support clients with activities they enjoy, including easy options, so they stay happy and involved.
userStoryBSummary: As an older adult, I want to control all communication with family and friends and avoid unwanted messages, allowing only chats I initiate.
resolutionDescription: The conflict is a Start-Forbid type. Both user stories are updated to clarify that ALFRED may initiate communication only with user consent or in ways that respect the older adult's control, balancing caregiver support and user autonomy.
newUserStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want ALFRED to support clients with enjoyable activities, including communication options that respect user control, so they stay happy and involved.
newUserStoryBSummary: As an older adult, I want to control all communications and allow ALFRED to send messages only when I agree, so I avoid unwanted contact.
